--- title: "Probability Definition - Axioms" image: "/images/biostats.jpg" date: "2024-12-10" format: html: fig-align: center page-layout: article toc: true toc-depth: 5 toc-expand: true lightbox: false filters: - highlight-text crossref: custom: - kind: float reference-prefix: "Example C.2." key: tabset space-before-numbering: false editor_options: chunk_output_type: console --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Methods of assigning probability - Probability ranges between $0$ and $1$ and describes how likely an event is to occur. - Probability can be assigned to events by different ways: [{{< iconify emojione-monotone:letter-a size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} **Subjective probability**: - This measures how an individual feels or is confident that an event will occur. - This is based on personal judgment and experience, not on repeated trials. - It is simple but less reliable. - For example, a person may feel that the probability of rain today is $30\%$. [{{< iconify emojione-monotone:letter-b size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} **Relative frequency approach**: - This is an objective way that depends on repeating an experiment many times and counting the number of times an event occurs. - The probability of an event $A = \displaystyle \frac{m}{n}$, where $m$ is the number of times event $A$ occurs and $n$ is the total number of trials. - As the number of the trials $n$ increases and tends to infinity, keeping the experimental conditions constant, the probability of the event $A$ converges to a limiting value interpreted as the probability of event $A$: $$ \text{Probability of}\ A = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{m}{n} $$ - In this context, the relative frequency approach is an approximation or an estimate of the probability of the event. - This approach is referred to as a posteriori concept of probability because it is based on empirical data or experimentation (i.e., calculated after the experiment is conducted.) - For example, if we toss a fair coin $1000$ times and get $480$ heads, then the probability of getting a head is $\large \frac{480}{1000} = 0.48$. When the number of trials increases and $n$ tends to infinity, the probability of getting a head will converge to $0.5$. ::: {.callout-note style="color: #0466c8;"} - A fair coin means that the probability of getting a head is equal to the probability of getting a tail $= 0.5$. ::: [{{< iconify emojione-monotone:letter-c size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} **Classical approach**: - This is based on abstract reasoning and is used when all outcomes are **equally likely**. - If an experiment has mutually exclusive and equally likely $N$ outcomes or simple events, then the probability of an event $A$ is given by: $$ \text{Probability of}\ A = \frac{N(A)}{N(S)} =\frac{\text{Number of elements in}\ A}{\text{Total number elements in the sample space}} $$ - This approach is referred to as a priori concept of probability because it is based on theoretical reasoning and not on empirical data or experimentation (i.e., there is no need to conduct an experiment to determine the probability of an event). - For example, refer to [Example C.1.1](/posts/biostats/C01_intro_prob_th.qmd#tabset-C11) in the previous section about rolling a single die: - All the six numbers are equally likely to occur, and the probability of getting any number is $\displaystyle \frac{1}{6}$. - The probability of getting an even number is equal to the number of elements in the event $B = \{2, 4, 6\}$ divided by the total number of elements in the sample space $S = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$: $$ \text{Probability of}\ B = \frac{N(B)}{N(S)} = \frac{3}{6} = 0.5 $$ - The probability of getting a number divisible by $3$ is equal to the number of elements in the event $D = \{3, 6\}$ divided by the total number of elements in the sample space: $$ \text{Probability of}\ D = \frac{N(D)}{N(S)} = \frac{2}{6} = \frac{1}{3} $$ - The probability of $B \cap D = \{6\}$ is equal to $\displaystyle \frac{1}{6}$. - As you notice, we do not need to roll the die to determine the probability of these events, rather we can determine them theoretically. ## Formal definition and axioms of probability ### Definition - The probability is a set function $P$ that assigns a number to each event in the sample space. - The probability of an event $A$ is denoted by $P(A)$. ### Axioms - Axioms refer to the basic or elementary rules of probability from which all other rules can be derived. [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} **Axiom 1**: - For an experiment with mutually exclusive outcomes, the probability of an event $A$ is a non-negative number (i.e., the probability is greater than or equal to $0$ and less than or equal to $1$): $$ 0 \le P(A) \le 1 $$ [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} **Axiom 2**: - The sum of probabilities of all the mutually exclusive outcomes of an experiment is equal to $1$, i.e., the probability of the sample space $S$ is equal to $1$: $$ P(A_1) + P(A_2) + P(A_3) + \ldots + P(A_n) = P(S) = 1 $$ [{{< iconify bi:3-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} **Axiom 3**: - For any two mutually exclusive events $A_1$ and $A_2$, the probability of the union of these events is equal to the sum of the probabilities of the individual events: $$ P(A_1 \cup A_2) = P(A_1) + P(A_2) $$ ::: {.callout-note style="color: #0466c8;"} - When the events are not mutually exclusive (i.e., they can occur simultaneously), then the probability of their union will be $P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)$, this is discussed in detail below. - The third axiom can be extended to more than two events: $P(A_1 \cup A_2 \cup A_3 \cup \ldots \cup A_n) = P(A_1) + P(A_2) + P(A_3) + \ldots + P(A_n)$ ::: ### Other probability rules [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} $P(A) = 1 - P(A')$ ::: {.callout-note style="color: #0466c8;" title="Proof"} - $P(A \cup A') = P(A) + P(A') = P(S) = 1$, then $P(A) = 1 - P(A')$. ::: [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} $P(\emptyset) = 0$ ::: {.callout-note style="color: #0466c8;" title="Proof"} - $P(\emptyset) = P(S') = 1 - P(S) = 1 - 1 = 0$. ::: [{{< iconify bi:3-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} If $A \subseteq B$, then $P(A) \leq P(B)$ ::: {.callout-note style="color: #0466c8;" title="Proof"} - As shown in the Venn diagram below, $B$ is the bigger circle, $A$ is the smaller green circle, and $A'$ is the blue area, therefore, $B = A \cup (B \cap A')$. - Then, $P(B) = P(A) + P(B \cap A') \ge P(A)$. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](C02_def_prob_th_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: [{{< iconify bi:4-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} If $A$ and $B$ are two non-mutually exclusive events, then: $$ P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B) $$ ::: {.callout-note style="color: #0466c8;" title="Explanation"} - Because the union of $A$ and $B$ contains the elements in $A$ **or** $B$ **or** both, we count the elements in $A$ and $B$ and subtract the elements in both groups (i.e., $A \cap B$) to avoid double counting. ::: ::: panel-tabset ## Example C.2.1 {{< iconify ic:round-menu-book size=21px >}} A pharmaceutical company is conducting clinical trials for two new drugs. The company's research director believes that the probability of the first drug receiving regulatory approval is $0.3$, the probability of the second drug receiving regulatory approval is $0.7$, and the probability of both drugs receiving regulatory approval is $0.2$. [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} What is the probability that the company receives approval for at least one drug? [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} What is the probability that the company receives approval for the first drug but not the second drug? [{{< iconify bi:3-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} What is the probability that the company receives approval for neither drug? [{{< iconify bi:4-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} What is the probability that the company receives approval for exactly one drug? **Answer** - Let $A$ be the event that the first drug is approved and $B$ be the event that the second drug is approved: $$ P(A) = 0.3, \quad P(B) = 0.7, \quad P(A \cap B) = 0.2 $$ [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} The probability that the company receives approval for at least one drug means either the first drug is approved or the second drug is approved or both are approved (i.e., $A \cup B$): $$ P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B) = 0.3 + 0.7 - 0.2 = 0.8 $$ ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](C02_def_prob_th_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} The probability that the company receives approval for the first drug but not the second drug means the first drug is approved and the second drug is not approved ($A \setminus B$): $$ P(A \setminus B) = P(A \cap B') = P(A) - P(A \cap B) = 0.3 - 0.2 = 0.1 $$ ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](C02_def_prob_th_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: [{{< iconify bi:3-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} The probability that the company receives approval for neither drug means neither the first drug nor the second drug is approved \[i.e., $(A \cup B)'$\]: $$ P[(A \cup B)'] = 1 - P(A \cup B) = 1 - 0.8 = 0.2 $$ ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](C02_def_prob_th_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: [{{< iconify bi:4-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} The probability that the company receives approval for exactly one drug means either the first drug is approved and the second drug is not approved or the first drug is not approved and the second drug is approved (i.e., $A \setminus B$ or $B \setminus A$): $$ P[(A \setminus B) \cup (B \setminus A)] = [P(A) - P(A \cap B)] + [P(B) - P(A \cap B)] = $$ $$ P(A) + P(B) - 2P(A \cap B) = P(A \cup B) - P(A \cap B) = 0.8 - 0.2 = 0.6 $$ ## [Exercise C.2.1 {{< iconify fluent:chat-bubbles-question-20-filled size=21px >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} -
